text:
“On an ordinary sheet of paper?” Raskolnikov asked eagerly.

“Just the most ordinary,” Porfiry replied, a hint of irony in his eyes.

Raskolnikov felt a flash of suspicion. “He knows,” he thought.

“Forgive my troubling you about such trifles,” he said, disconcerted. 

Razumihin chimed in, “That’s why you were struck when I mentioned Porfiry.”

Raskolnikov shot him a glare, anger flaring in his dark eyes.

“Are you jeering at me?” he snapped, feigning irritation.

“I’m not selfish,” he insisted. “This watch is all I have left of my father.” 

Razumihin laughed. Raskolnikov clenched his fists, fighting back.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov expresses his anxiety over a lost silver watch that holds sentimental value, despite its low monetary worth.
